title: Fasting and True Obedience
shortSummary: Zechariah 7 addresses the question of whether the people should continue fasting in the fifth month as they had done for many years. God, through the prophet Zechariah, challenges the people to understand that true fasting is not merely outward ritual but involves sincere obedience, justice, and mercy toward others. The chapter emphasizes the importance of heartfelt repentance and social righteousness as evidence of genuine devotion to God.
timeline: c. 520 BC - Early Persian Period during the reign of King Darius

keyCharacters.name: Zechariah
keyCharacters.description: The prophet who receives and delivers God's message concerning fasting and obedience to the returned exiles.

keyCharacters.name: King Darius
keyCharacters.description: The Persian king during whose reign Zechariah prophesies; the fourth year of his reign marks the time of this prophecy.

keyCharacters.name: Sherezer and Regemmelech
keyCharacters.description: Leaders sent to the house of God to inquire about fasting and prayer practices.

keyCharacters.name: The Priests and Prophets
keyCharacters.description: Religious leaders in the house of the LORD who receive the inquiry and the prophetic response.

definitions.definition: The month of Av (Chisleu in the ninth month is mentioned for the timing of the prophecy), traditionally a time of mourning for the destruction of Jerusalem.
An act of abstaining from food and drink as a form of penitence and seeking God's favor.
A very hard, unyielding stone symbolizing stubbornness and refusal to listen or obey.
Righteous and just treatment of others, reflecting God's standards of justice and mercy.

outline.heading: Inquiry About Fasting
outline.description: Leaders inquire of the priests and prophets whether they should continue the traditional fasting in the fifth month, reflecting the people's concern about religious observance after exile.

outline.heading: God’s Question on the Purpose of Fasting
outline.description: God challenges the people through Zechariah, asking if their fasting was truly directed toward Him or merely for their own benefit, highlighting the need for sincere worship.

outline.heading: Call to Justice and Mercy
outline.description: The LORD commands the people to practice true justice, mercy, and compassion toward one another, emphasizing ethical living as the heart of true fasting.

outline.heading: Rebellion and Judgment
outline.description: The people’s refusal to listen to God's prophets led to their scattering among the nations and desolation of the land, illustrating the consequences of disobedience.

application: Examine your motives in religious practices to ensure they honor God sincerely rather than serving personal or cultural traditions.
Live out your faith by actively practicing justice, mercy, and compassion toward others, especially the vulnerable.
Be attentive and obedient to God’s Word as revealed through Scripture and His messengers, avoiding hardness of heart.
Recognize that true repentance involves both inward humility and outward actions that reflect God’s character.

keyVerses.text: When ye fasted and mourned in the fifth and seventh month, even those seventy years, did ye at all fast unto me, even to me?
keyVerses.significance: This verse challenges the superficiality of ritual fasting and calls for genuine devotion to God.

keyVerses.text: Thus saith the LORD of hosts, saying, Execute true judgment, and shew mercy and compassions every man to his brother:
keyVerses.significance: It highlights the essential qualities God desires from His people—justice, mercy, and compassion.

keyVerses.text: Yea, they made their hearts as an adamant stone, lest they should hear the law, and the words which the LORD of hosts hath sent in his spirit by the former prophets: therefore came a great wrath from the LORD of hosts.
keyVerses.significance: This verse warns against stubbornness and disobedience to God’s revealed word, which brings judgment.

keyVerses.text: But I scattered them with a whirlwind among all the nations whom they knew not. Thus the land was desolate after them, that no man passed through nor returned: for they laid the pleasant land desolate.
keyVerses.significance: It explains the consequence of persistent disobedience—exile and desolation of the land.
